questions.question: Memory type that loses data when power is removed.
questions.explanation: Volatile memory like RAM requires continuous power to maintain stored data.

questions.question: Memory type that retains data even without power.
questions.explanation: Non-volatile memory like ROM, SSDs, and HDDs keep data permanently.

questions.question: Fast memory built into the CPU chip.
questions.explanation: L1 cache is the fastest and smallest cache directly on the processor.

questions.question: The standard interface used to connect SSDs and HDDs to motherboards.
questions.explanation: SATA is the Serial ATA interface for connecting storage devices.

questions.question: Storage interface faster than SATA, often used for modern SSDs.
questions.explanation: NVMe uses PCIe lanes for significantly faster data transfer than SATA.

questions.question: A group of 8 bits.
questions.explanation: A byte consists of 8 bits and is the basic unit for measuring storage.

questions.question: Type of RAM that must be constantly refreshed to maintain data.
questions.explanation: DRAM stores data in capacitors that need periodic refreshing.

questions.question: Type of RAM that is faster and doesn't need refreshing.
questions.explanation: SRAM uses flip-flops to store data and is faster but more expensive than DRAM.

questions.question: Storage technology that writes data once but can be read many times.
questions.explanation: CD-R and DVD-R are write-once, read-many optical storage media.

questions.question: Storage that can be erased and rewritten multiple times.
questions.explanation: Flash memory in SSDs and USB drives can be written and erased repeatedly.
